intro: Abies magnifica f. glauca, commonly known as the whitebark pine, is a variant of the whitebark pine tree native to the western United States. It is characterized by its blue-gray foliage, which gives it a distinctive appearance. The tree has a slow growth rate and develops a broad, conical shape with thick, furrowed bark. Its needles are short, stiff, and arranged in bundles of five, and it produces cones that are typically 3–5 inches long. This variety is adapted to high-altitude environments and is often found in subalpine and alpine zones.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abies magnifica f. glauca is primarily native to the mountainous regions of western North America, particularly in the Sierra Nevada and Cascade Range. This subspecies is found in high elevation forests, typically at elevations between 1,500 and 3,000 meters. It thrives in cool, moist climates with well-drained soils, often growing in mixed coniferous forests. The plant is adapted to the harsh conditions of alpine environments, including strong winds and limited sunlight. Its distribution is limited to specific areas where the climate and soil conditions are suitable for its growth.

It is commonly found in the Sierra Nevada and other high-altitude forests where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade.
